{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2966752,"name":"EricRehder","username":"EricRehder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/7ab992/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-08-28T23:48:38.868Z","cooked":"

Hello, I’m a coach that is learning the coding side to help team 6658 since we have lost all our coders. I have coding experience but I’m trying to learn Java and the FRC environment. The WPI guides are pretty good, but they are based on interfacing to a fully assembled robot. Is it possible to power on a RoboRio, connect with USB, deploy code, and work on basic coding to interface between the joystick, DIO, analog IO, etc?

I can deploy example code from the Visual Studio. Roborio imaging works fine. In the driver station I have green LED for Enet Link, Robot, Wifi, and USB. So it seems to be OK.

But the Drive station Communications and Robot Code LEDs are red. And I can’t Enable the code.

Is there a problem in my setup? in my code? I’m not sure how to interpret the error messages.

image1281×292 58.9 KB

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-08-28T23:48:38.868Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":51,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":285.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395772,"topic_slug":"running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio","display_username":"EricRehder","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/0/6/0687e4c8b07c7ac333b4df04f2b62043958cd2ae.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":32451,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio/395772/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2966763,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-29T01:55:12.701Z","cooked":"

So a few parts:

In general, yes, I expect code deployed to a roborio on a power supply should run as “normal”. That being said, expect analogous problems to what you would have running code in simulation: since the real hardware isn’t there, you have to expect errors or “different” behavior, and devise ways to test around it.

The lack of connectivity you are seeing isn’t something I’d expect to see from a lack of other hardware.

Has the roborio been updated with the latest image? Do all laptops have the same symptom when connecting to the “test board”?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-08-29T01:55:21.316Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":135,"readers_count":134,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":395772,"topic_slug":"running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio/395772/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2966814,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-29T14:16:45.436Z","cooked":"

This should work, but if you are trying to use things that are on CAN (as an example), you might see crashes. Be sure you configured the team number when you set up the RIO.

Do the “Communications” or “Robot Code” ever flicker? You can click on the gear icon at the top of the mostly blank large pane to the right of the driver station and select “+ prints” and/or look for any output in the pane that opens in Visual Studio when you run the code; this might provide some more clues (even confirming nothing shows up there could be a further clue).

Also, check to be sure windows firewall is off. You might want to run through this troubleshooter.

This is a valid point. If the code in robot periodic or robit init crashes in the right way, it produces this kind of behavior. Oftentimes it occurs when io assignments are invalid (for instance A Can bus that does not exist or two motor controllers assigned to the same port number etc.)

nuttle:

Also, check to be sure windows firewall is off. You might want to run through this troubleshooter.

Specifically, the screenshot shows that the windows firewall is on.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2021-08-29T23:24:20.004Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":38.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395772,"topic_slug":"running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/running-code-on-a-standalone-roborio/395772/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2966873,"name":"Sean W - 2421 Software Mentor","username":"seanw","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/seanw/{size}/120003_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-30T15:52:44.530Z","cooked":"

Once you get communication going, consider velcroing the Rio to a piece of plywood and then attaching a few motors and some sensors/lights as a way to do robot things without needing a full on robot to drive around. Building a testing rig - #18 by seanw is the one we use for most of our development.
